incidents.name: Docker Hub Registry Timming Out

incident_updates.body: The DockerHub incident has been marked as resolved, and we are not observing any ongoing issues.

You may be seeing an issue with downloading your Docker Hub Image.
Error pulling image <image>: Error response from daemon: Get "https://registry-1.docker.io/v2/": net/http: request canceled (Client.Timeout exceeded while awaiting headers)... retrying

This is due to an active DockerHub Incident. 
More information can be found on the Docker Hub Status Page: https://www.dockerstatus.com/pages/533c6539221ae15e3f000031

components.name: Docker Hub

incident_updates.body:
Between 1:17 PM and 1:27 PM UTC a small percentage of builds failed to be triggered for organizations that use our Github App integration.

If you experienced this issue, please trigger your pipeline again. This will work as normal now.

incidents.name: Builds failed to trigger for organizations with Github App integration

incident_updates.body:
Between 1:31 PM and 1:45 PM UTC a small percentage of builds failed to trigger for organizations that use Github App integration.

If you were affected by this issue, please try triggering your pipeline again. We apologize for the inconvenience caused.

incidents.name: Triggering pipelines and creating new environment variables returning 401 or 404 errors

incident_updates.body:
Between 10:18 UTC and 10:31 UTC, users may have seen unexpected 401 or 404 responses when triggering a pipeline or creating new environment variables.

In case you were affected by this error, please try triggering your pipeline or creating the environment variables again. These should work as expected now.

incident_updates.body: The incident is now resolved. Any PRs or commits that did not trigger a pipeline will not be re-run. Pipelines can be manually triggered in the CircleCI UI or by sending an empty commit using git's `--allow-empty` option.

We are continuing to see no further impact from this incident. Any PRs or commits that did not trigger a pipeline will not be re-run. Pipelines can be manually triggered in the CircleCI UI or by sending an empty commit using git's `--allow-empty` option.
We have implemented a fix for the issue and we are now seeing pipelines triggering as normal. We are continuing to monitor the situation.
We have identified the cause of the issue and are taking measures to mitigate the impact.
We have identified an issue causing VCS webhooks receiving a 500 error, causing pipelines to not be triggered in CircleCI. We are investigating to identify the cause.

We have identified the cause and have implemented a fix. We have seen a drop in the 429 errors across test jobs. We are continuing to monitor the status.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are seeing an increase in 429 "Too Many Requests" errors when test splitting using the CircleCI test plugin. We are investigating to identify the cause.

incidents.name: SSH Connections on Remote Docker

incident_updates.body:
For a brief period between 13:28 UTC and 14:05 UTC we made a change on Remote Docker executors affecting `known_hosts` preventing some SSH connections, including those to GitHub, from being possible. This did not affect GitHub checkouts.

We have since reverted the change and are now seeing normal behaviour.

We have found that users are having success reloading and re-running builds.

incidents.name: GitHub Checks are delayed

incident_updates.body:
## Incident Report: 2023-03-14 - Delays Starting Jobs

## Summary:

On March 14, 2023, at approximately 18:00 UTC, all customers' pipelines began to experience delays in starting, ultimately resulting in jobs not running. This incident lasted until approximately 01:27 UTC. In short, an ongoing Kubernetes upgrade created a version mismatch between kubelet and kubeproxy, leading to widespread networking failures in our main production cluster. The remediation efforts for this incident also led to two incidents caused by errors in our queuing system using RabbitMQ queues and nodes, from 02:50 to 05:14 UTC, where all customer pipelines experienced delays, and from 09:50 to 13:15 UTC where GitHub checks were delayed by as much as 30 minutes.

The original status page updates can be found here: [Jobs not starting](https://status.circleci.com/incidents/dcqb3fykhgvg), [Jobs not starting cont'd](https://status.circleci.com/incidents/9c9nq4p6wx3x) and [GitHub Checks are delayed](https://status.circleci.com/incidents/h86y8k0ypthl).

We want to thank our customers for your patience and understanding as we worked to resolve this incident.

## What Happened

In the week prior to this event, our infrastructure team had been slowly carrying out an upgrade of our main production Kubernetes cluster. On March 13th, 2023, after updating a few components, some services started reporting missing metrics. We proceeded to revert the changes and things seemingly recovered as the metrics came back. After reviewing and adjusting the plan to limit the blast radius, at approximately 17:40 UTC on March 14th, we attempted a different approach to upgrading these components. At 18:00 UTC, we started seeing an increase in communication errors on one of our services. As more engineers and teams joined the incident call, we could see that we were facing a much more widespread impact throughout multiple services and on all functionalities of the application. As the delays in job processing continued to climb and as our job queues started backing up across multiple services, we restarted a few services in an attempt to mitigate some of the symptoms we were seeing. Soon, it became clear that the issues were stemming from failures in service-to-service communication, and within an hour, the initial degraded state of the application became a significant incident.

After continued investigation, digging through logs, metrics, and attempts to connect to services using internal Kubernetes domain names directly from the pods, we suspected that the networking issues leading to communication failures were either due to `kube-proxy`, `core-dns` or `node-local-dns-cache`. This was difficult to verify, as all of those workloads appeared to be healthy.

Between 20:00 and 21:00 UTC, we decided to restart node-local-dns-cache and core-dns, which caused DNS resolution to fail completely. The team was starting to hone in on `kube-proxy` as the main culprit and the restart of one of the nodes gave us more confidence as we noticed that requests related to that node were going through. At this point, we continued on the restart path and restarted every node. By 23:00, all the nodes were rolled out and we had started seeing recovery except for those jobs using contexts or machine executor. We then restarted a separate pool of dependencies and by 01:15 UTC, March 15th, all jobs were executing correctly.

During recovery, we identified that were missing logging for RabbitMQ, so to complete our mitigation efforts, we rolled the rest of our infrastructure. At approximately 02:50 UTC RabbitMQ connection errors led to another episode of delayed jobs that we were able to mitigate by 03:35 UTC. This second incident was fully resolved by 05:14 UTC.

A subsequent restart of the RabbitMQ nodes was carried out to fix a few corrupted queues that caused another degradation in GitHub checks at 09:50 UTC, March 15th. We mitigated the issue by 11:08 UTC and after a long period of monitoring the situation, the incident was fully resolved at 13:15 UTC.

## Post Incident Contributing Events Analysis:

Due to the broad impact of the networking issues, a complete restart of the cluster was ultimately needed to mitigate this issue. At the time of mitigation, it was evident that something in our Kubernetes upgrade process was responsible for this networking failure and further analysis was needed to see what we missed. Upon review, we identified that at the onset of the incident, `kube-proxy`, a network proxy running on every `node` in the Kubernetes cluster had a spike of "Sync failed" errors.

```shell
"Failed to execute iptables-restore" err="exit status 1 (iptables-restore: line 8022 failed\n)"
"Sync failed" retryingTime="30s"
```

To understand what’s happening here, it’s important to understand the role of `Kube-proxy` in a cluster. `Pods` \(smallest deployable units\) in a cluster have a temporary life cycle. They are ephemeral by nature and are terminated or created as required. Usually, each pod is running a single instance of an application. They are able to reach each other using unique IP addresses that are assigned to them. These IP addresses can change without warning in response to events such as scaling or failures. A set of pods in a cluster are load-balanced by a `Service` object. Services are also assigned a virtual IP address and leverage an `Endpoints` object to keep track of what pods are available at any given time. `Kube-proxy`, as noted above, runs on each node of the cluster and watches the `Service` and `Endpoints` objects. When changes occur in these objects, updates the routing rules on the host nodes are updated using `iptables` \(the default execution mode for `kube-proxy`\) a Linux firewall utility that allows or blocks traffic based on defined rules and policies. In a nutshell, `kube-proxy` consumes these `Endpoints` objects and modifies the local node's `iptables` to implement a local load balancer for each Service's virtual IP. As pods are created or destroyed in response to events, `kube-proxy` reconciles the rulesets on the node against the available `Endpoints`.

In the course of its normal operation `kube-proxy` performs a read/modify/write operation in the [Proxier.syncProxyRules\(\)](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/bc4763cbf8b9e6adfbc07bb3194509b187b0b901/pkg/proxy/iptables/proxier.go#L795) method. This method uses the system `iptables-save` and `iptables-restore` commands to read in the state, create new rules, and write the state back out. Between the two Kubernetes versions we were working with, the handling and format of `kube-proxy'`s rulesets changed.

What we did not notice was when we rolled back the `kube-proxy` version on March 13th, a very small amount of `Sync-failure` errors started showing up in our logs as visible in the graph below.

![](https://global.discourse-cdn.com/circleci/original/3X/9/a/9a1ba3057da89a317e7088dcb6fb2ffde2c8a4a9.jpeg)
As we rolled out more pods and existing `Endpoints` objects changed in response to these events, `kube-proxy`attempted to sync and reconcile the `iptables` on the nodes and failed to do so. These errors increased as more changes to pods and services were introduced during the upgrade process and on March 14th, as we resumed the upgrade, a spike in `sync errors` left the `iptables` on multiple nodes in a very corrupted state.

![](https://global.discourse-cdn.com/circleci/original/3X/f/9/f95a209ec75979639a48fde4a1c25cbd67be6af3.jpeg)
When we restarted the node, a fresh `iptable` ruleset was created and as we completed a full restart of the clusters, the sync errors disappeared restoring networking within the cluster.

## Future Prevention and Process Improvement:

As we analyzed the contributing factors, we realized that there was not one single trigger that led to this incident. Due to the foundational nature of networking, Kubernetes upgrade are inherently risky and our risk mitigation strategies were not effective in the scenario where an interaction of multiple events ultimately triggered this incident. Our infrastructure engineering team is enhancing our Kubernetes upgrade process in order to significantly limit this risk model for future upgrades. In addition, we have enhanced observability with additional metrics and alerts specifically related to the sync errors being thrown by `kube-proxy` during the incident.

Additionally, we are evaluating strategies to improve the resilience of our RabbitMQ infrastructure.

Once again, we thank you for your patience as we worked to mitigate the incident and perform a thorough analysis of the events that caused this incident. Our goal remains to continue to improve the resilience and reliability of our application.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our March 15th incident: https://stspg.io/yxr6lkkcdgn2

incident_updates.body: We are continuing to see usual service levels for GitHub Checks updates. This incident is now resolved.

We made a number of changes to mitigate the impact of the delayed checks. We have seen a downward trend of delayed GitHub Checks, and are now seeing usual activity. We will monitor the current activity.
We are continuing to work on a fix for the delayed GitHub Checks.
We have identified the cause of the delayed Checks and are actively working on a fix.
We are currently observing a delay with GitHub Checks of up to 30 minutes. We are currently working to identify the cause of the issue.

incidents.name: Jobs not starting cont'd

incident_updates.body:
On March 14, 2023 starting at 18:00 UTC we experienced a failure in our internal networking system. As a result some internal traffic was routed incorrectly. We originally thought the issue was isolated to a few services, but soon concluded the problem impacted most services.

Once we had identified this was a systemic failure, we decided that a restart of our internal cloud infrastructure was required. After the initial restart was complete, the UI, API, and some docker jobs were working.

We then discovered that the networking problem had unexpectedly impacted other infrastructure systems which required more restarts. At the same time, we had problems spinning up resources to process the backlog of machine jobs.

By 01:30 UTC all restarts had completed, and jobs were running with slight delays for Mac and Machine jobs. By 02:40 UTC, all resource types were running with normal delays.

At 02:50 UTC as a precaution, we decided to restart infrastructure that was not directly impacted by the networking issue. During that restart we experienced some delays starting jobs, but were able to immediately identify the issue. By 04:00 UTC all job types were running again.

We will publish a full incident report here. To be notified when it is published, please subscribe to status page updates on [status.circleci.com](http://status.circleci.com/).

‌

Update 03/23/23

## Incident Report: 2023-03-14 - Delays Starting Jobs

## Summary:

On March 14, 2023, at approximately 18:00 UTC, all customers' pipelines began to experience delays in starting, ultimately resulting in jobs not running. This incident lasted until approximately 01:27 UTC. In short, an ongoing Kubernetes upgrade created a version mismatch between kubelet and kubeproxy, leading to widespread networking failures in our main production cluster. The remediation efforts for this incident also led to two incidents caused by errors in our queuing system using RabbitMQ queues and nodes, from 02:50 to 05:14 UTC, where all customer pipelines experienced delays, and from 09:50 to 13:15 UTC where GitHub checks were delayed by as much as 30 minutes.

The original status page updates can be found here: [Jobs not starting](https://status.circleci.com/incidents/dcqb3fykhgvg), [Jobs not starting cont'd](https://status.circleci.com/incidents/9c9nq4p6wx3x) and [GitHub Checks are delayed](https://status.circleci.com/incidents/h86y8k0ypthl).

We want to thank our customers for your patience and understanding as we worked to resolve this incident.

## What Happened

In the week prior to this event, our infrastructure team had been slowly carrying out an upgrade of our main production Kubernetes cluster. On March 13th, 2023, after updating a few components, some services started reporting missing metrics. We proceeded to revert the changes and things seemingly recovered as the metrics came back. After reviewing and adjusting the plan to limit the blast radius, at approximately 17:40 UTC on March 14th, we attempted a different approach to upgrading these components. At 18:00 UTC, we started seeing an increase in communication errors on one of our services. As more engineers and teams joined the incident call, we could see that we were facing a much more widespread impact throughout multiple services and on all functionalities of the application. As the delays in job processing continued to climb and as our job queues started backing up across multiple services, we restarted a few services in an attempt to mitigate some of the symptoms we were seeing. Soon, it became clear that the issues were stemming from failures in service-to-service communication, and within an hour, the initial degraded state of the application became a significant incident.

After continued investigation, digging through logs, metrics, and attempts to connect to services using internal Kubernetes domain names directly from the pods, we suspected that the networking issues leading to communication failures were either due to `kube-proxy`, `core-dns` or `node-local-dns-cache`. This was difficult to verify, as all of those workloads appeared to be healthy.

Between 20:00 and 21:00 UTC, we decided to restart node-local-dns-cache and core-dns, which caused DNS resolution to fail completely. The team was starting to hone in on `kube-proxy` as the main culprit and the restart of one of the nodes gave us more confidence as we noticed that requests related to that node were going through. At this point, we continued on the restart path and restarted every node. By 23:00, all the nodes were rolled out and we had started seeing recovery except for those jobs using contexts or machine executor. We then restarted a separate pool of dependencies and by 01:15 UTC, March 15th, all jobs were executing correctly.

During recovery, we identified that were missing logging for RabbitMQ, so to complete our mitigation efforts, we rolled the rest of our infrastructure. At approximately 02:50 UTC RabbitMQ connection errors led to another episode of delayed jobs that we were able to mitigate by 03:35 UTC. This second incident was fully resolved by 05:14 UTC.

A subsequent restart of the RabbitMQ nodes was carried out to fix a few corrupted queues that caused another degradation in GitHub checks at 09:50 UTC, March 15th. We mitigated the issue by 11:08 UTC and after a long period of monitoring the situation, the incident was fully resolved at 13:15 UTC.

## Post Incident Contributing Events Analysis:

Due to the broad impact of the networking issues, a complete restart of the cluster was ultimately needed to mitigate this issue. At the time of mitigation, it was evident that something in our Kubernetes upgrade process was responsible for this networking failure and further analysis was needed to see what we missed. Upon review, we identified that at the onset of the incident, `kube-proxy`, a network proxy running on every `node` in the Kubernetes cluster had a spike of "Sync failed" errors.

```shell
"Failed to execute iptables-restore" err="exit status 1 (iptables-restore: line 8022 failed\n)"
"Sync failed" retryingTime="30s"
```

To understand what’s happening here, it’s important to understand the role of `Kube-proxy` in a cluster. `Pods` \(smallest deployable units\) in a cluster have a temporary life cycle. They are ephemeral by nature and are terminated or created as required. Usually, each pod is running a single instance of an application. They are able to reach each other using unique IP addresses that are assigned to them. These IP addresses can change without warning in response to events such as scaling or failures. A set of pods in a cluster are load-balanced by a `Service` object. Services are also assigned a virtual IP address and leverage an `Endpoints` object to keep track of what pods are available at any given time. `Kube-proxy`, as noted above, runs on each node of the cluster and watches the `Service` and `Endpoints` objects. When changes occur in these objects, updates the routing rules on the host nodes are updated using `iptables` \(the default execution mode for `kube-proxy`\) a Linux firewall utility that allows or blocks traffic based on defined rules and policies. In a nutshell, `kube-proxy` consumes these `Endpoints` objects and modifies the local node's `iptables` to implement a local load balancer for each Service's virtual IP. As pods are created or destroyed in response to events, `kube-proxy` reconciles the rulesets on the node against the available `Endpoints`.

In the course of its normal operation `kube-proxy` performs a read/modify/write operation in the [Proxier.syncProxyRules\(\)](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/bc4763cbf8b9e6adfbc07bb3194509b187b0b901/pkg/proxy/iptables/proxier.go#L795) method. This method uses the system `iptables-save` and `iptables-restore` commands to read in the state, create new rules, and write the state back out. Between the two Kubernetes versions we were working with, the handling and format of `kube-proxy'`s rulesets changed.

What we did not notice was when we rolled back the `kube-proxy` version on March 13th, a very small amount of `Sync-failure` errors started showing up in our logs as visible in the graph below.

![](https://global.discourse-cdn.com/circleci/original/3X/9/a/9a1ba3057da89a317e7088dcb6fb2ffde2c8a4a9.jpeg)
As we rolled out more pods and existing `Endpoints` objects changed in response to these events, `kube-proxy`attempted to sync and reconcile the `iptables` on the nodes and failed to do so. These errors increased as more changes to pods and services were introduced during the upgrade process and on March 14th, as we resumed the upgrade, a spike in `sync errors` left the `iptables` on multiple nodes in a very corrupted state.

![](https://global.discourse-cdn.com/circleci/original/3X/f/9/f95a209ec75979639a48fde4a1c25cbd67be6af3.jpeg)
When we restarted the node, a fresh `iptable` ruleset was created and as we completed a full restart of the clusters, the sync errors disappeared restoring networking within the cluster.

## Future Prevention and Process Improvement:

As we analyzed the contributing factors, we realized that there was not one single trigger that led to this incident. Due to the foundational nature of networking, Kubernetes upgrade are inherently risky and our risk mitigation strategies were not effective in the scenario where an interaction of multiple events ultimately triggered this incident. Our infrastructure engineering team is enhancing our Kubernetes upgrade process in order to significantly limit this risk model for future upgrades. In addition, we have enhanced observability with additional metrics and alerts specifically related to the sync errors being thrown by `kube-proxy` during the incident.

Additionally, we are evaluating strategies to improve the resilience of our RabbitMQ infrastructure.

Once again, we thank you for your patience as we worked to mitigate the incident and perform a thorough analysis of the events that caused this incident. Our goal remains to continue to improve the resilience and reliability of our application.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published an initial postmortem on our March 14th incident: https://stspg.io/0lv0ytv98tlj

Docker, Mac, Machine and other jobs should are running operational. We are continuing monitoring the situation. We appreciate your patience.
We are seeing jobs are becoming operational. We will continue to monitor the situation.
We are currently seeing issues with jobs not starting. We have identified the issue and we are working to fix this.

incidents.name: Jobs not starting

incident_updates.body:
## Incident Report: 2023-03-14 - Delays Starting Jobs

## Summary:

On March 14, 2023, at approximately 18:00 UTC, all customers' pipelines began to experience delays in starting, ultimately resulting in jobs not running. This incident lasted until approximately 01:27 UTC. In short, an ongoing Kubernetes upgrade created a version mismatch between kubelet and kubeproxy, leading to widespread networking failures in our main production cluster. The remediation efforts for this incident also led to two incidents caused by errors in our queuing system using RabbitMQ queues and nodes, from 02:50 to 05:14 UTC, where all customer pipelines experienced delays, and from 09:50 to 13:15 UTC where GitHub checks were delayed by as much as 30 minutes.

The original status page updates can be found here: [Jobs not starting](https://status.circleci.com/incidents/dcqb3fykhgvg), [Jobs not starting cont'd](https://status.circleci.com/incidents/9c9nq4p6wx3x) and [GitHub Checks are delayed](https://status.circleci.com/incidents/h86y8k0ypthl).

We want to thank our customers for your patience and understanding as we worked to resolve this incident.

## What Happened

In the week prior to this event, our infrastructure team had been slowly carrying out an upgrade of our main production Kubernetes cluster. On March 13th, 2023, after updating a few components, some services started reporting missing metrics. We proceeded to revert the changes and things seemingly recovered as the metrics came back. After reviewing and adjusting the plan to limit the blast radius, at approximately 17:40 UTC on March 14th, we attempted a different approach to upgrading these components. At 18:00 UTC, we started seeing an increase in communication errors on one of our services. As more engineers and teams joined the incident call, we could see that we were facing a much more widespread impact throughout multiple services and on all functionalities of the application. As the delays in job processing continued to climb and as our job queues started backing up across multiple services, we restarted a few services in an attempt to mitigate some of the symptoms we were seeing. Soon, it became clear that the issues were stemming from failures in service-to-service communication, and within an hour, the initial degraded state of the application became a significant incident.

After continued investigation, digging through logs, metrics, and attempts to connect to services using internal Kubernetes domain names directly from the pods, we suspected that the networking issues leading to communication failures were either due to `kube-proxy`, `core-dns` or `node-local-dns-cache`. This was difficult to verify, as all of those workloads appeared to be healthy.

Between 20:00 and 21:00 UTC, we decided to restart node-local-dns-cache and core-dns, which caused DNS resolution to fail completely. The team was starting to hone in on `kube-proxy` as the main culprit and the restart of one of the nodes gave us more confidence as we noticed that requests related to that node were going through. At this point, we continued on the restart path and restarted every node. By 23:00, all the nodes were rolled out and we had started seeing recovery except for those jobs using contexts or machine executor. We then restarted a separate pool of dependencies and by 01:15 UTC, March 15th, all jobs were executing correctly.

During recovery, we identified that were missing logging for RabbitMQ, so to complete our mitigation efforts, we rolled the rest of our infrastructure. At approximately 02:50 UTC RabbitMQ connection errors led to another episode of delayed jobs that we were able to mitigate by 03:35 UTC. This second incident was fully resolved by 05:14 UTC.

A subsequent restart of the RabbitMQ nodes was carried out to fix a few corrupted queues that caused another degradation in GitHub checks at 09:50 UTC, March 15th. We mitigated the issue by 11:08 UTC and after a long period of monitoring the situation, the incident was fully resolved at 13:15 UTC.

## Post Incident Contributing Events Analysis:

Due to the broad impact of the networking issues, a complete restart of the cluster was ultimately needed to mitigate this issue. At the time of mitigation, it was evident that something in our Kubernetes upgrade process was responsible for this networking failure and further analysis was needed to see what we missed. Upon review, we identified that at the onset of the incident, `kube-proxy`, a network proxy running on every `node` in the Kubernetes cluster had a spike of "Sync failed" errors.

```shell
"Failed to execute iptables-restore" err="exit status 1 (iptables-restore: line 8022 failed\n)"
"Sync failed" retryingTime="30s"
```

To understand what’s happening here, it’s important to understand the role of `Kube-proxy` in a cluster. `Pods` \(smallest deployable units\) in a cluster have a temporary life cycle. They are ephemeral by nature and are terminated or created as required. Usually, each pod is running a single instance of an application. They are able to reach each other using unique IP addresses that are assigned to them. These IP addresses can change without warning in response to events such as scaling or failures. A set of pods in a cluster are load-balanced by a `Service` object. Services are also assigned a virtual IP address and leverage an `Endpoints` object to keep track of what pods are available at any given time. `Kube-proxy`, as noted above, runs on each node of the cluster and watches the `Service` and `Endpoints` objects. When changes occur in these objects, updates the routing rules on the host nodes are updated using `iptables` \(the default execution mode for `kube-proxy`\) a Linux firewall utility that allows or blocks traffic based on defined rules and policies. In a nutshell, `kube-proxy` consumes these `Endpoints` objects and modifies the local node's `iptables` to implement a local load balancer for each Service's virtual IP. As pods are created or destroyed in response to events, `kube-proxy` reconciles the rulesets on the node against the available `Endpoints`.

In the course of its normal operation `kube-proxy` performs a read/modify/write operation in the [Proxier.syncProxyRules\(\)](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/bc4763cbf8b9e6adfbc07bb3194509b187b0b901/pkg/proxy/iptables/proxier.go#L795) method. This method uses the system `iptables-save` and `iptables-restore` commands to read in the state, create new rules, and write the state back out. Between the two Kubernetes versions we were working with, the handling and format of `kube-proxy'`s rulesets changed.

What we did not notice was when we rolled back the `kube-proxy` version on March 13th, a very small amount of `Sync-failure` errors started showing up in our logs as visible in the graph below.

![](https://global.discourse-cdn.com/circleci/original/3X/9/a/9a1ba3057da89a317e7088dcb6fb2ffde2c8a4a9.jpeg)
As we rolled out more pods and existing `Endpoints` objects changed in response to these events, `kube-proxy`attempted to sync and reconcile the `iptables` on the nodes and failed to do so. These errors increased as more changes to pods and services were introduced during the upgrade process and on March 14th, as we resumed the upgrade, a spike in `sync errors` left the `iptables` on multiple nodes in a very corrupted state.

![](https://global.discourse-cdn.com/circleci/original/3X/f/9/f95a209ec75979639a48fde4a1c25cbd67be6af3.jpeg)
When we restarted the node, a fresh `iptable` ruleset was created and as we completed a full restart of the clusters, the sync errors disappeared restoring networking within the cluster.

## Future Prevention and Process Improvement:

As we analyzed the contributing factors, we realized that there was not one single trigger that led to this incident. Due to the foundational nature of networking, Kubernetes upgrade are inherently risky and our risk mitigation strategies were not effective in the scenario where an interaction of multiple events ultimately triggered this incident. Our infrastructure engineering team is enhancing our Kubernetes upgrade process in order to significantly limit this risk model for future upgrades. In addition, we have enhanced observability with additional metrics and alerts specifically related to the sync errors being thrown by `kube-proxy` during the incident.

Additionally, we are evaluating strategies to improve the resilience of our RabbitMQ infrastructure.

Once again, we thank you for your patience as we worked to mitigate the incident and perform a thorough analysis of the events that caused this incident. Our goal remains to continue to improve the resilience and reliability of our application.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our March 15th incident: https://stspg.io/t6yynwrr9m0b

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved. Docker, Mac, Machine jobs should be running correctly.
Machine jobs are now running, we expect the backlog to clear over the next hour.  We will continue to monitor.
We are seeing Docker and Mac jobs are now  becoming operational. We are seeing Machine jobs are starting to run, but we are still monitoring for capacity issues.

We've identified a problem in our internal networking systems that triggered the issue and made changes to configuration and deployments to address the issue.

Docker jobs with contexts are starting to run successfully. We will continue to monitor for further issues with Contexts.
We are still working to add capacity for machine jobs.
UI access remains stable. We are still tuning capacity and resources to process backlogs. We appreciate your patience and understanding.
UI and API access has mostly recovered. We are still working through capacity issues for Machine jobs and Contexts.
We are continuing to add capacity to process the backlog of jobs. We appreciate your patience.
We are seeing jobs running again, and are adding additional capacity.
We are seeing intermittent successes in the UI as some components have been recovered. We are continuing to work on getting jobs moving and will update shortly with status on jobs.

Our debugging efforts have led to partial recovery of some internal services. We are seeing intermittent success on user actions and continue to work on restoration. We'll report back in under 20 mins as we see the impact.
We are continuing to see degradation on our services including jobs not starting and UI impacts. We are currently investigating networking issues and will update further within 30 mins.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are continuing to investigate this issue. Thank you for your patience while we work toward a resolution.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are continuing our investigation. Currently jobs are delayed in starting and not completing.
We are seeing a delay in starting jobs. We are currently investigating and will update shortly.

incidents.name: Vendor Billing Issue

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

Beginning on February 6th, 2023, we began receiving reports that customers were experiencing billing issues when attempting to sign-up for services, refill credits, or renew plans. We have opened a ticket with our billing vendor and they have confirmed the issue and are currently working on a fix.

The number of customers affected by this issue appears to be small, but if you are having difficulty signing up or renewing your billing, please reach out via our Support Portal (https://support.circleci.com/hc/en-us) so we ensure your service with CircleCI is uninterrupted.

incidents.name: Workflows Status Errors

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved. Workflow status should be reporting correctly. Please let us know if you are continuing to encounter issues with your pipelines' status.
For a period of 10 minutes, Some workflows will have some errors in getting status in UI and API. We are currently monitoring.

incidents.name: Intel-based macOS jobs are not starting

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We are observing recovery in our macOS jobs and are monitoring.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are currently investigating this issue. This is only impacting macOS jobs run on Intel-Based executors.

components.name: macOS Jobs
components.description: CircleCI jobs using the macos executor.

incidents.name: Some Windows executors pinning to `current` are failing.

incident_updates.body:
We have identified that the failing images were pushed at 2023-02-22 00:20 UTC and the fixed image was published at 2023-02-22 10:26 UTC. Any builds with the affected image tags between these timestamps may remain in a stalled state. Users will need to cancel and re-run these jobs if required.

The incident is now resolved.
We have implemented a fix and builds are now running as normal. We are continuing to monitor the status.

An issue with the Windows `windows-server-2022-gui:current` and `2023.02.1` tags are causing builds to stall on `Preparing environment` step. This will also impact those using the Windows orb with `server-2022` and `default` executors. We have identified the issue and are working on a fix.

components.name: Windows Jobs
components.description: Jobs using the Windows executor.

incidents.name: Irregular Job Performance

incident_updates.body: On February 17th, an update was pushed to our job running cluster which caused some jobs to seemingly disappear from the UI and others to run longer than usual. The change was reverted on February 27th. It is estimated that 5% of tasks were affected.

incidents.name: Job Delays

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.
We are currently experiencing delays with jobs. All jobs are affected. We are investigating this issue.

incidents.name: Delays Processing Jobs

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved
We have resolved the issue and are seeing job start-up times execute within their expected timeframes. We will continue to monitor the stability of our platform.
We have identified the issue and are working towards mitigating the delay of job start-up times.
We are continuing to investigate the cause of this issue.
We are currently seeing delays in processing all jobs. We are in the process of investigating the cause of this issue.

incidents.name: Jobs Completing Inconsistently

incident_updates.body: Starting at 15:33 UTC we saw some customer’s jobs complete inconsistently causing workflows to not report a completed status. We addressed the behavior by 15:37 UTC and jobs should now complete normally when triggering new builds

incidents.name: Delay in GitHub Checks Integration

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We have addressed the issue, and are monitoring the stability of our systems as we process the backlog of delayed GitHub Checks.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.
